text: I love growing corn, but I've made a ton of mistakes growing corn even this year. So in this video, I'm going to go over all the different mistakes you might be making from your corn so you can have an incredible harvest. So here we are in my backyard, mini corn patch. This is the third one I've grown this year. I have a huge patch of corn I'm going to show you in just a second. But at the end of the video, I'm going to open up an ear and we'll see if I have good pollination and a good ear of corn. Right now, call today that like button for epic ears and let's crack in to the mistakes. The first mistake and the most critical is just not planting enough corn. When I get messages from you guys saying what's wrong with my corn, it's usually just because you only have a couple of stocks of corn. It needs a lot. I would say a block of at least four feet by four feet because it's a wind pollinated plant. This is the male part, the tassel right here. It literally drops pollen down. You can see it's blowing in the wind right now. If you don't have enough, the pollen is just going to kind of blow away. It has to land on the silks, which is the female part, and actually traverse down those silks into the ear to pollinate each individual kernel. So the problem you're going to run into is by not planting enough, the pollen just simply won't hit the silks and you will not get enough corn. Mistake number two is spotty germination. Corn is a big seed, but it's a very hard seed. And so when you direct sow it in the ground, much like we did here in this attempted corn maze, you can see the outer row just really didn't germinate. And the reason why is because after it sprouted up, our irrigation system just didn't get enough water out to this corner here or really any of the corners around the whole maze. I do have a little maze here, so it's still kind of cool. But what you need to think about with corn is making sure that the moisture level is consistent the entire time you're germinating it. You can start corn indoors or in trays and transplant. The only thing I would say is it tends to take a little bit to settle in. So when you're germinating corn, make sure you lay down maybe some mulch to lock in that moisture or make sure that you're irrigating the entire patch. Mistake number three is improper soil preparation. So here in the corn patch on the Epic Home setting channel, you can see exactly what we did if you want to, but we basically leveled the ground out and tilled in a very healthy amount of compost. Now, I know we often don't till here in the gardening world. I simply did not have enough nutrition in this soil, specifically nitrogen to make sure that the corn was growing nice and tall. Corn loves nitrogen. So you need to loosen the soil up and you need to add in a healthy amount of organic matter. So if you're in a situation where that's not the case, maybe it would have germinated, maybe it would have even grown a little bit, but without proper nutrition and with way too compact of soil, it would have stood no chance. The fourth mistake you can run into with corn is just improper fertilization. So corn is actually a grass. It's not a grain contrary to what you might think. We've evolved it over time through selection, and it's just a really crazy specific grass. So what does grass need? It's a leafy plant. It needs nitrogen. So if you have too little nitrogen in your soil, that's probably going to be the number one deficiency that your corn will have. So how do you fix that? Well, a great way to do that is to use any sort of organic, granular fertilizer. I personally think that chicken manure, especially from your own chickens, if you can do it is a great way to do it because chicken manure is extremely high in nitrogen and that nitrogen is very active. But if you're seeing stunted growth, light yellowing leaves, nitrogen is probably the problem. Mistake number five, watering. You can really mess your corn up with improper watering. It's a plant that wants to remain more or less constantly moist in the soil. Remember, it's growing really tall, has a lot of structure to build. And so one of the best ways to do that is to put it on some kind of irrigation or just make sure you don't forget to water. It needs at least an inch or two every single week. And the best way to make sure you keep it there is some kind of mulch. Whatever is local to you is great. We're huge fans of straw here at Epic Gardening, but you can use fallen leaves if you're in a more cold climate that actually has leaves that fall. We don't have that here, so I'm a little jealous. But some sort of mulch, three, even four inches is great to lock that moisture in. Mistake number six is your corn just kind of flopping over. You can see this one just it's falling. Well, part of the reason why is because it's become a little top heavy. These are some big, healthy years that they need to get harvested. But if you transplant your corn, I sometimes recommend transplanting a little bit deeper because corn being such a tall plant, having a lot of leaves, catching the wind and being a wind pollinated plant, you kind of want it in an area that gets some airflow, but it can topple over. So if you transplant, transplant a little bit deeper. And if not, sometimes you can even just tie your corn together, sort of in a big bunch, like take some twine kind of tied together so it all supports itself. Or if you're really getting particular, you can individually stake with some bamboo stakes, keep it upright so it doesn't crack itself in half before it's ready to harvest. Our last set of mistakes really comes at the critical point of the harvest. So I'm going to harvest one for you right now and talk about how you really can mess this up. So remember, these are the soaks. These are the female part of the plant. They need to look completely dead. So about, I don't know, 18 to 22 days after your silk's form, it's when you should at least be thinking about harvesting the corn. So this one here, to be honest with you, is probably still not quite ready. You want to have these soaks so dry that you could almost slap them and they just come right off. You can also give it a bit of a feel and kind of see, hey, how's this feeling? I actually feel there's a little mistake probably in this corn. So let me open up one that's perfectly ready right now. Take a look at these soaks. What you have is very dry soaks, very brown. If I pull lightly, they come right out. Now, even this might be slightly early, but hey, I'm going to show it to you. Anyways, a good way to test while the plant is still intact. Well, you haven't removed it. You can actually just peel this down just a little bit, just enough to reveal the tip of the ear. There we go. So I've got pretty good pollination here. You can see there's there's a little problem in here that I'll talk about in a second. But what you want to do is you want to kind of just poke one of these kernels with your fingertip, come in, give it a little poke. And you want to see sort of a milky fluid come out. If you see that, you're in a good spot. If it's kind of gummed up and a little bit then you're waiting too long. And if you don't see anything at all and it's just really small and informed, you've waited not long enough. It's a little bit too early. So let me pull the rest of this off and I'll discuss a couple more mistakes that you might find. So first of all, overall, we have a really nice ear of corn here. But there's this guy. Now, this guy is a corn worm. This little guy is the bane of growing corn. I wouldn't so much call this a mistake. It's just a thing that happens. It's a moth that lays an egg right at the top, comes in, munches off. We've harvested this early enough that it actually hasn't eaten too much. So you might say, this is gross. Like I'm not going to eat this corn. Don't be like that. Don't be like that. Just cut the tip off. We'll feed these to our chickens in a second. But this is overall a really solid ear of corn. Now, let me show you what happens when maybe that corn ear is not so solid. OK, let's put this down for a second and let's harvest this guy right here. Now, how do I know it's not quite ready? Well, these don't come off quite as easily. Right, they're not quite there yet. I can't just tug them right off. I still see like pretty intact silks right here. And I'm squeezing it and I'm knowing that I haven't really pollinated this top bit, but a good sign is that the ear is kind of pushing away from the main stock, showing that the base is developed enough to kind of force it away. So let's crack it off, twist it. And let's see what we've got in here. So I'm already going to guess that the tip is not going to be pollinated. So here's what happens when you don't have perfect pollination. Now, this is still a pretty good ear of corn. If I pop the kernel, I'm still in a pretty good spot here. But you can see how the silk just didn't all the way pollinate the tip. And I also have one of those cornworms here. So what do you do in this case? I would say don't beat yourself up. It's really not that big a deal. Again, you can just cut this off and you have a pretty good ear of corn. Oftentimes when the very, very tip doesn't pollinate, it just means that the weather might have been too hot, water might have been a little bit low. And it's going to prioritize these kernels down here. So let me toss those cornworms to the chickens and we'll give this a little bite and see how it tastes. Like I said, don't waste an entirely good ear just because something weird was at the top. What I like to do is just chop that tip off. That'll go to the chickens as well. And I'll give this a rinse and a quick taste. So this is a sweet corn. Don't do this with a dent or a flour corn, but you can eat corn straight off of the stock. I think it's still a little bit better personally cooked, but it is quite nice this way. Mmm, perfectly sweet. You know, you hit it right when you get that little milky residue coming out. It is so delicious and so sweet. Gros-Yohan's Sweet Corn Guys, hopefully these mistakes help. Subscribe for more tips. Good luck in the garden and keep on growing.
